titleInfo.title: Extrinsic Incentives, Voting Behavior, and Public Opinion
titleInfo.subTitle: Three Studies of the Influence of Extrinsic Incentives over Voting Choices, Turnout, and Attitudes Toward Clientelism

name.namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy

mods:mods.abstract: This dissertation includes three studies that discuss the influence of extrinsic incentives on voting behavior and public opinion. In the first study, I propose a formal model that aims to explain how extrinsic incentives, the perceptions of voters about receiving these incentives, and the electoral environment affect individuals' voting choices. I find equilibria that show that yielding to the influence of exogenous incentives–whether they are material or immaterial–is a best strategy under not very stringent conditions. Then, I illustrate the predictions from the model using three cases where it has been observed that material or immaterial incentives affected–or still affect–the behavior of voters: vote-buying and voter coercion during the United States Gilded Age, the electoral behavior of African-Americans, and religious voting. The second study evaluates the effect on electoral participation of a turnout-buying program implemented in the state of Chihuahua in Mexico. Using a difference-in-difference design, with the states of Sinaloa and Zacatecas as control cases, I find evidence that suggests that this program has not met its goal of incentivizing participation. I also use a triple difference-in-difference design to explore if the program may have only had an effect on urban municipalities. The results of these additional estimations confirm that, at least at the municipality level, the program has not increased turnout. Finally, the third study explores a public opinion aspect of a phenomenon related to extrinsic incentives. Using data from the LAPOP AmericasBarometer Mexico 2018 survey, I address the question of the existence of social desirability bias regarding clientelism in Mexican public opinion. The results indicate that respondents that revealed that they had received a clientelist offer seemed to try and distance themselves from these offers by giving more negative evaluations of clientelism. This finding suggests that social desirability bias is present as respondents seem to use the evaluation question as a way to distance themselves from the offer they claimed to have received.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Political Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
